    9125             : 
    9126         595 : static void process_auto_specifier(
    9127             :                                  a_boolean              auto_type_allowed,
    9128             :                                  a_boolean              first_specifier,
    9129             :                                  a_decl_flag_set        input_flags,
    9130             :                                  a_decl_parse_state     *state,
    9131             :                                  a_decl_pos_block_ptr   decl_pos_block,
    9132             :                                  a_decl_specifiers_set  *decl_specifiers_seen,
    9133             :                                  a_basic_type           *basic_type,
    9134             :                                  a_type_ptr             *type_ptr,
    9135             :                                  a_boolean              *err)
    9136             : /*
    9137             : Process the "auto" or "decltype(auto)" specifier.  Depending on the mode,
    9138             : "auto" can be a storage class specifier, a type specifier, or both.  If it can
    9139             : be both, we cannot determine which it is until all specifiers have been seen,
    9140             : and this routine is called late (i.e., after all specifiers have been seen).
    9141             : If it cannot be both, this routine is called early because in
    9142             :     typedef int T; T x;
    9143             :     void f() { auto T(x); }
    9144             : we must know that a type specifier ("auto") was seen to avoid treating T as a
    9145             : type specifier (here, it is a declarator-id).
    9146             : auto_type_allowed is TRUE if the current context allows "auto" as a type
    9147             : specifier.  first_specifier is TRUE if "auto"/"decltype(auto)" was the first
    9148             : specifier other than "inline" or "friend".  input_flags are the flags passed
    9149             : to decl_specifier (for which this is a helper routine).  *state and
    9150             : *decl_pos_block track various properties of the current declaration parsing
    9151             : state; they may be updated by this routine.  *decl_specifiers_seen records the
    9152             : kind of specifiers seen (and may be updated).  *basic_type and *type_ptr
    9153             : describe the type specified by the specifiers and are updated if
    9154             : "auto"/"decltype(auto)" is treated as a type specifier.  *err is set to TRUE
    9155             : if an error is issued.
    9156             : */
    9157             : {
    9158         595 :   if (auto_type_specifier_enabled &&
    9159         595 :       (!auto_storage_class_specifier_enabled ||
    9160           0 :        state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen ||
    9161           0 :        (!(*decl_specifiers_seen & DS_TYPE) &&
    9162           0 :         (input_flags & DSI_TYPE_SPECIFIER_ALLOWED)))) {
    9163             :     /* Either this is "decltype(auto)" or else it is "auto" in a mode where
    9164             :        "auto" can be a type specifier.  In the "auto" case, it cannot be a
    9165             :        storage class specifier because this mode doesn't allow it or because
    9166             :        no other type specifier was seen. */
    9167         595 :     if (!auto_type_allowed ||
    9168         595 :         (*decl_specifiers_seen & (DS_TYPE | DS_VOID)) != 0 ||
    9169         595 :         ((input_flags & DSI_IS_PARAMETER) != 0 &&
    9170           0 :          state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen)) {
    9171             :       /* If the current mode supports "auto" as a type specifier, but the
    9172             :          current context does not (e.g., a typedef declaration), issue an
    9173             :          error that is specific for "auto" but does not imply whether it is a
    9174             :          type specifier or a storage class.  If "decltype(auto)" is used for a
    9175             :          parameter type, issue an error specific to "decltype(auto)".
    9176             :          Otherwise, if a type specifier has already been seen, report a bad
    9177             :          combination of type specifiers. */
    9178           0 :       an_error_code  err_code = state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen ?
    9179           0 :                                            ec_decltype_auto_not_allowed_here :
    9180             :                                            ec_auto_not_allowed_here;
    9181           0 :       if (auto_type_allowed &&
    9182           0 :           !((input_flags & DSI_IS_PARAMETER) != 0 &&
    9183             :             state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen)) {
    9184           0 :         err_code = ec_bad_combination_of_type_specifiers;
    9185             :       }  /* if */
    9186           0 :       pos_error(err_code, &state->auto_pos);
    9187           0 :       *basic_type = bt_error;
    9188           0 :       *type_ptr = error_type();
    9189           0 :       *err = TRUE;
    9190           0 :       discard_placeholder_type(state);
    9191             :     } else {
    9192         595 :       *basic_type = bt_auto;
    9193        1190 :       state->auto_type = make_auto_type(&state->auto_pos,
    9194         595 :                                         state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen);
    9195         595 :       *type_ptr = state->auto_type;
    9196             :     }  /* if */
    9197         595 :     *decl_specifiers_seen |= DS_TYPE;
    9198             :   } else {
    9199             :     /* "auto" must be a storage class specifier. */
    9200           0 :     state->auto_type_specifier_seen = FALSE;
    9201           0 :     state->has_deduced_type = FALSE;
    9202           0 :     process_storage_class_specifier(
    9203             :                                tok_auto, input_flags, state, decl_pos_block,

    9293          35 : static void scan_specifier_attributes(a_decl_flag_set     flags,
    9294             :                                       a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
    9295             :                                       a_boolean           *std_attr_seen)
    9296             : /*
    9297             : Scan specifier attributes and record them in *dps.  flags is the set of input
    9298             : flags passed to the call of decl_specifiers (which in turn called this
    9299             : function).  Issue a diagnostic if attributes appear in a context that doesn't

    9345             : static void preapply_declspec_attributes(a_decl_parse_state  *dps)
    9346             : /*
    9347             : Check for the presence of certain __declspec attributes (which at this point
    9348             : haven't yet been applied to the entity that will presumably be declared), and
    9349             : adjust *dps accordingly.
    9350             : Set dps->is_declspec_property_field if a __declspec(property(...)) attribute
    9351             : was seen and the current scope is a class scope (issue a diagnostic and
    9352             : disable the "property" attribute if the current scope is not a class scope).
    9353             : If the __declspec(dllimport) or __declspec(dllexport) were seen, perform some
    9354             : early check and adjustments:
    9355             :   - Check that both are not present simultaneously.
    9356             :   - Set dps->decl_modifiers accordingly.
    9357             :   - If __declspec(dllimport) is present without any storage class specifier,
    9358             :     set the storage class to sc_extern.
    9359             : (Note: The general attributes application mechanism doesn't actually record
    9360             : the DLL flags.  That is done elsewhere using dps->decl_modifiers.flags.)
    9361             : */
    9362             : {
    9363             :   an_attribute_ptr  ap = find_attribute(ak_property, dps->prefix_attributes);
    9364             : 
    9365             :   if (ap != NULL) {
    9366             :     if (scope_stack_top().kind != (a_scope_kind)sck_class_struct_union) {
    9367             :       pos_st_error(ec_attr_must_appear_in_class_definition, &ap->position,
    9368             :                    ap->name);
    9369             :       make_attr_unrecognized(ap);
    9370             :     } else {
    9371             :       dps->is_declspec_property_field = TRUE;
    9372             :       dps->is_property_or_event_field = TRUE;
    9373             :     }  /* if */
    9374             :   }  /* if */

    9385             : 
    9386     4511890 : static void attach_specifier_attributes(a_decl_parse_state  *dps)
    9387             : /*
    9388             : Attach "specifier attributes" to the type indicated by the specifiers (which
    9389             : produces a new type).  For standard C++11 attributes, "specifier attributes"
    9390             : are in principle those attributes that were scanned after seeing the
    9391             : decl-specifiers.  E.g., in
    9392             :   [[noreturn]] int [[XYZ::abc]] f();
    9393             : [[noreturn]] is a prefix attribute and [[XYZ::abc]] is a specifier attribute.
    9394             : In GNU mode, however, there is no distinction between prefix and specifier
    9395             : attributes; instead, each attribute kind either applies to the declaration as
    9396             : a whole or to the specifiers type.  E.g.:
    9397             :   __attribute((vector_size(16))) int __attribute((noreturn)) g();
    9398             : is equivalent to
    9399             :   __attribute((noreturn)) int __attribute((vector_size(16))) g();
    9400             : (the vector_size attribute applies to the specifiers type and the noreturn
    9401             : attribute applies to the declaration as a whole).
    9402             : Similarly, Microsoft compilers make no distinction between prefix __declspec
    9403             : attributes and specifier attributes (unlike GNU attributes, there are no
    9404             : type-modifying __declspec attributes).
    9405             : This routine therefore moves any entries on the dps->specifier_attributes list
    9406             : that don't apply to types to the dps->prefix_attributes list.  Conversely, any
    9407             : entries on the dps->prefix_attributes that do transform types are moved to the
    9408             : dps->specifier_attributes list.
    9409             : */
    9410             : {
    9411     4511890 :   if (dps->prefix_attributes != NULL || dps->specifier_attributes != NULL) {
    9412         277 :     an_attribute_ptr  to_prefix = NULL, to_specifier = NULL;
    9413         277 :     an_attribute_ptr  *end_to_prefix, *end_to_specifier, *end_specifier, *p_ap;
    9414         277 :     end_to_prefix = &to_prefix;
    9415         277 :     end_to_specifier = &to_specifier;
    9416             :     /* First move any non-type attributes from the specifiers list to the
    9417             :        prefix list. */
    9418         277 :     p_ap  = &dps->specifier_attributes;
    9419         312 :     while (*p_ap != NULL) {
    9420          35 :       if (!is_type_transforming_attribute(*p_ap) &&
    9421          35 :           (!is_unapplicable_attr(*p_ap) ||
    9422             :            /* In a case like: "__attribute__((X)) auto f() -> int;" ensure that
    9423             :               the unrecognized attribute isn't attached to the "auto" type. */
    9424           0 :            (is_gcc_attribute(*p_ap) &&
    9425           0 :             is_auto_type(dps->specifiers_type)))) {
    9426             :         /* Move the attribute to the prefix attributes list. */
    9427          35 :         an_attribute_ptr  ap = *p_ap;
    9428          35 :         if (is_std_attribute(ap) && !ap->is_std_gcc_attribute &&
    9429           0 :             !(c11_mode && ap->family == (a_byte_attribute_family)af_alignas)) {
    9430           0 :           report_bad_attribute_target(gpp_mode ? es_warning : es_error, ap);
    9431             :         }  /* if */
    9432          35 :         *p_ap = ap->next;
    9433          35 :         ap->next = NULL;
    9434          35 :         ap->syntactic_location = (a_byte_attribute_location)al_prefix;
    9435          35 :         if (ap->kind == (a_byte_attribute_kind)ak_enable_if) {
    9436           0 :           dps->pending_prefix_enable_if_attr = TRUE;
    9437             :         }  /* if */
    9438          35 :         *end_to_prefix = ap;
    9439          35 :         end_to_prefix = &ap->next;
    9440             :       } else {
    9441             :         /* Proceed to the next attribute. */
    9442           0 :         p_ap = &(*p_ap)->next;
    9443             :       }  /* if */
    9444             :     }  /* while */
    9445         277 :     end_specifier = p_ap;
    9446             :     /* Now move any type attributes from the prefix list to the specifiers
    9447             :        list. */
    9448         277 :     p_ap  = &dps->prefix_attributes;
    9449         519 :     while (*p_ap != NULL) {
    9450         242 :       if (is_type_transforming_attribute(*p_ap) &&
    9451           0 :           !is_unapplicable_attr(*p_ap)) {
    9452             :         /* Move the attribute to the specifier attributes list. */
    9453           0 :         an_attribute_ptr  ap = *p_ap;
    9454           0 :         if (is_std_attribute(ap) && !ap->is_std_gcc_attribute) {
    9455           0 :           report_bad_attribute_target(es_error, ap);
    9456             :         }  /* if */
    9457           0 :         *p_ap = ap->next;
    9458           0 :         ap->next = NULL;
    9459           0 :         ap->syntactic_location = (a_byte_attribute_location)al_specifier;
    9460           0 :         *end_to_specifier = ap;
    9461           0 :         end_to_specifier = &ap->next;
    9462             :       } else {
    9463         242 :         if ((*p_ap)->kind == (a_byte_attribute_kind)ak_enable_if) {
    9464           0 :           dps->pending_prefix_enable_if_attr = TRUE;
    9465             :         }  /* if */

    9695             : 
    9696     4511890 : void decl_specifiers(a_decl_flag_set       input_flags,
    9697             :                      a_decl_parse_state    *state,
    9698             :                      a_decl_pos_block_ptr  decl_pos_block)
    9699             : /*
    9700             : Scan a list of declaration specifiers (e.g., the nonterminal grammar token
    9701             : declaration-specifiers in the C standard or the similar decl-specifier-seq in
    9702             : the C++ standard) according to options passed through input_flags.  The
    9703             : results of the scan are summarized in *state, with some additional position
    9704             : information stored in *decl_pos_block.
    9705             : 
    9706             : The concept of "declaration specifiers" includes standard constructs such as
    9707             : those corresponding to the nonterminal grammar token declaration-specifiers
    9708             : in the C standard or the similar decl-specifier-seq in the C++ standard, but
    9709             : also various nonstandard constructs (e.g., the Microsoft __declspec(...)
    9710             : mechanism).  For GNU and Microsoft extensions, we generally implement actual
    9711             : behavior rather than documented behavior whenever the two differ.
    9712             : 
    9713             : Descriptions of the various input_flag options follow the definition of the
    9714             : macro DSI_NO_INPUT_FLAGS.
    9715             : 
    9716             : A change in this function that affects C++ syntax almost always requires a
    9717             : corresponding change in prescan_decl_specifiers (in disambig.c).
    9718             : */
    9719             : {
    9720     4511890 :   a_symbol_ptr               curr_token_type_symbol;
    9721     4511890 :   a_boolean                  err = FALSE;
    9722     4511890 :   a_boolean                  bad_combination_of_type_specifiers = FALSE;
    9723     4511890 :   a_boolean                  is_parameter =
    9724     4511890 :                                         (input_flags & DSI_IS_PARAMETER) != 0;
    9725     4511890 :   a_boolean                  is_member_decl =
    9726     4511890 :                                (input_flags & DSI_IS_MEMBER_DECLARATION) != 0;
    9727     4511890 :   a_boolean                  vacuous_decl_allowed;
    9728     4511890 :   a_boolean                  specifier_allows_vacuous_decl;
    9729     4511890 :   a_boolean                  declares_something = FALSE;
    9730     4511890 :   a_boolean                  defines_something = FALSE;
    9731     4511890 :   a_boolean                  type_specifier_allowed, auto_type_allowed;
    9732     4511890 :   a_boolean                  dangling_type_specifier = FALSE;
    9733     4511890 :   a_boolean                  is_elaborated_type_specifier = FALSE;
    9734     4511890 :   an_error_severity          es = es_none;
    9735     4511890 :   a_basic_type               basic_type = bt_none;
    9736             : #if GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    9737     4511890 :   an_error_code              delayed_error = ec_no_error;
    9738     4511890 :   a_source_position          pos_delayed_error;
    9739             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    9740     4511890 :   a_type_sign                sign = sign_none;
    9741     4511890 :   a_type_size                size = size_none;
    9742     4511890 :   a_complex_attribute        complex_attr = cxa_none;

    9819             :                                         &error_position);

    9857             :            determines the type of a variable declaration from its initializer

    9859             :            restrictions). */
    9860           0 :         if (!type_specifier_allowed) {
    9861           0 :           pos_error(ec_type_specifier_not_allowed, &error_position);

    9863           0 :         } else if (basic_type != bt_none) {

   11041             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   11042        1250 :       case tok_decltype:
   11043             :         /* This could be decltype(auto), decltype(...)::... or just a plain
   11044             :            decltype specifier.  The first case is handled here, and the others
   11045             :            in the fall-through path. */
   11046        1250 :         if (decltype_auto_enabled && decltype_auto_tokens_next()) {
   11047          32 :           check_assertion(auto_type_specifier_enabled);
   11048          32 :           if (state->auto_type_specifier_seen ||
   11049             :               state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen) {
   11050           0 :             pos_error(ec_bad_combination_of_type_specifiers, &pos_curr_token);
   11051             :           } else {
   11052          32 :             auto_is_first = !(decl_specifiers_seen & ~(DS_INLINE | DS_FRIEND));

   11054          32 :             state->has_deduced_type = TRUE;
   11055          32 :             state->decltype_auto_specifier_seen = TRUE;
   11056          32 :             process_auto_specifier(
   11057             :                     decltype_auto_enabled, auto_is_first, input_flags, state,
   11058             :                     decl_pos_block, &decl_specifiers_seen, &basic_type,
   11059             :                     type_ptr, &err);
   11060             :           }  /* if */
   11061             :           /* Consume the four tokens of "decltype(auto)". */
   11062          32 :           (void)get_token();
   11063          32 :           (void)get_token();
   11064          32 :           (void)get_token();
   11065          32 :           (void)get_token();
   11066          32 :           goto no_get_token;
   11067             :         }  /* if */
   11068             :         /*FALLTHROUGH*/
   11069             :       case tok_identifier:  /* Identifier or "::". */
   11070             :       case tok_colon_colon:
   11071             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   11072             :       case tok_super:
   11073             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   11074             :         /* Identifier. */
   11075             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
   11076     6831120 :         id_start_pos = pos_curr_token;
   11077             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
   11078             :         /* The appearance of an identifier may mean that the specifiers
   11079             :            are complete (the identifier is a declarator) or it may be another
   11080             :            specifier.  First we look for conditions that will cause us to
   11081             :            exit the loop -- generally because the identifier is clearly not
   11082             :            a specifier.  Note that when we get here with a decltype token
   11083             :            this could be a simple "decltype(x)" or the start of a qualified
   11084             :            name (e.g., "decltype(x)::something").  In the former case,
   11085             :            the call to process_nontype_identifier will return FALSE and
   11086             :            the current token will be a tok_decltype_construct, which is
   11087             :            handled below. */
   11088             :         /* To be more specific: in ANSI C, an identifier that appears to be
   11089             :            a typedef name is not recognized as such if the specifiers list
   11090             :            already includes a basic type or sign.  This is so that the
   11091             :            following (from the standard, 3.5.6) will work:
   11092             :                typedef signed int t;
   11093             :                main () {
   11094             :                  long t;    <-- This declares a new identifier t.
   11095             :                }
   11096             :            K&R (first edition, Appendix A, section 11.1) also includes the
   11097             :            following:
   11098             :                typedef float distance;
   11099             :                {
   11100             :                  auto int distance;
   11101             :                }
   11102             :            but pcc (at least on a Sun 3) doesn't accept this.  It always
   11103             :            seems to scan a typedef name as a typedef name.  To conform to
   11104             :            K&R, we consider an identifier to be a typedef when there is
   11105             :            just a sign or size (since these are "adjectives" to pcc), but
   11106             :            not when there is a type specifier. */

   11916             :       }  /* if */
   11917             :     }  /* if */
   11918             : #if UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   11919        9397 :   } else if (upc_mode && !err) {
   11920             :     /* The UPC strict and relaxed qualifiers can only appear combined with
   11921             :        the shared qualifier. */
   11922           9 :     if ((qualifiers & (TQ_UPC_STRICT | TQ_UPC_RELAXED)) != 0 &&
   11923           0 :         (qualifiers & TQ_UPC_SHARED) == 0) {
   11924           0 :       pos_error(ec_nonshared_strict_relaxed, &error_position);
   11925           0 :       err = TRUE;
   11926             :     }  /* if */
   11927             : #endif /* UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   11928             :   }  /* if */
   11929             :   /* If there was an error, assume something was declared.  Who knows what the
   11930             :      correct code should have done. */
   11931     4511890 :   if (err || declares_something) *output_flags |= DSO_DECLARES_SOMETHING;
   11932     4511890 :   if (defines_something) *output_flags |= DSO_DEFINES_SOMETHING;
   11933             : #if DEBUG
   11934     4511890 :   if (debug_level >= 3) {
   11935           0 :     fputs("type_ptr: ", f_debug);
   11936           0 :     if (*type_ptr == NULL) {
   11937           0 :       fputs("<null>", f_debug);
   11938             :     } else {
   11939           0 :       db_type(*type_ptr);
   11940             :     }  /* if */
   11941           0 :     (void)fputc('\n', f_debug);
   11942             :   }  /* if */
   11943             : #endif /* DEBUG */
   11944     4511890 :   state->storage_class = state->declared_storage_class;
   11945     4511890 :   state->decl_specifiers_error = err;
   11946     4511890 :   attach_specifier_attributes(state);
   11947             :   /* state->type and state->declared_type may get updated by a subsequent call
   11948             :      to declarator(...) or by other adjustments (e.g., decay of array types to
   11949             :      pointer types). */
   11950     4511890 :   state->type = state->declared_type = state->specifiers_type;
   11951     4511890 :   if ((*output_flags & DSO_NO_DECL_SPECIFIERS) &&
   11952        4686 :       !state->is_linkage_spec_decl &&
   11953        4686 :       state->prefix_attributes == NULL &&
   11954        4686 :       state->specifier_attributes == NULL) {
   11955             :     /* Note that for the purposes of diagnostic, something like
   11956             :        ``extern "C" f();'' is treated as having a decl-specifier (hence the
   11957             :        test for !state->is_linkage_spec_decl). */
   11958        4686 :     state->decl_specifiers_omitted = TRUE;
   11959             :   }  /* if */
   11960     4511890 :   db_exit();
   11961     4511890 : }  /* decl_specifiers */
   11962             : 
   11963             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   11964             : 
   11965             : void scan_microsoft_secondary_decl_specifiers(
   11966             :                                          a_decl_flag_set       input_flags,
   11967             :                                          a_decl_parse_state    *state,
   11968             :                                          a_decl_pos_block_ptr  decl_pos_block)
   11969             : /*
   11970             : This is a wrapper function for decl_specifiers(...), to handle the scanning
   11971             : of Microsoft C++ mode decl-specifiers appearing after a comma separating
   11972             : multiple declarators (we call these "secondary specifiers").  Many specifiers
   11973             : result in an error in this context, and many others (including cv-qualifiers)
   11974             : are ignored with a warning.  "Primary cv-qualifiers" are preserved, however.
   11975             : For example:
   11976             :     int i1, char const* s1;       // s1 has type char*
   11977             :     int const i2, char* s2;       // s2 has type char const*
   11978             :     int i3, extern char* s3;      // "extern" is ignored
   11979             :     int i4, extern "C" char* s4;  // syntax error
   11980             : This Microsoft extension/bug is sometimes used in "for" statements:
   11981             :     for (char *p = s, int k = 0; ...
   11982             : 
   11983             : See decl_specifiers(...) for the meaning of the parameters.
   11984             : */
   11985             : {
   11986             :   a_type_qualifier_set    saved_qualifiers = state->qualifiers;
   11987             :   a_source_position       pos;
   11988             : 
   11989             :   check_assertion(ms_extensions && !C_mode());
   11990             :   pos = pos_curr_token;
   11991             :   input_flags &= ~(DSI_INLINE_ALLOWED | DSI_ASM_ALLOWED |
   11992             :                    DSI_EMPTY_DECL_SPECIFIERS_ALLOWED);
   11993             :   input_flags |= DSI_MICROSOFT_SECONDARY_SPECIFIERS;
   11994             :   decl_specifiers(input_flags, state, decl_pos_block);
   11995             :   /* Restore the primary cv-qualifiers: */
   11996             :   state->qualifiers = saved_qualifiers;
   11997             :   (void)add_type_qualifiers(&state->specifiers_type, state);
   11998             :   state->type = state->specifiers_type;
   11999             :   /* Issue a warning in most cases, but if a class or enumeration type was
   12000             :      defined make it an error. */
   12001             :   pos_diagnostic((state->dso_flags & DSO_DEFINES_SOMETHING) ? es_error
   12002             :                                                             : es_warning,
   12003             :                  ec_nonstandard_secondary_decl_specifiers, &pos);
   12004             : }  /* scan_microsoft_secondary_decl_specifiers */
   12005             : 
   12006             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   12007             : 
   12008         320 : void decl_spec_one_time_init(void)
   12009             : /*
   12010             : Do one-time initialization of variables related to the processing of
   12011             : decl-specifiers.
   12012             : */

   12014         320 :   if (!enum_types_can_be_larger_than_int) {

   12042             :                   auto_type_specifier_enabled);
   12043         320 : }  /* decl_spec_one_time_init */
